718919f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718919f-a.text:
(1)
City Hall Park: A rear view of the City Court, a brownstone
structure erected in 1852 on the site of the Rotunda (built in 1816, where
works of Art were exhibited). It was occupied by the Court of Special
Sessions and in 1879 by the Tax Offices. In the early part of 1929 it
was demolished. The Hall of Records, appearing on the right was wrected
in 1903.
November 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, obscuring the Hall of Records. Structure parti 1ly shown on
the right is the Municipal Building.
October 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

718913f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The old Hall of Records located at the S. W.
corner of Park Row and Chambers Street. Tho structure was erectod
in 1735 as a debtors prison. During the Revolution it was used as
a prison by the British. It was convertod to its present status
in 1840.
July 4, 1860

718938f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - N. Hale statue.
718938f-a.text:
City Hall Park: The Nathan Hale statue located in
the westerly portion; the Broadway side and viewed northeast-
ward towards Park Row. To the left is the City Hall, to the
Nright, the Tribune Building and in the center background, the
Pulitzer (World) Building.
King's Handbook of New York of 1893, page 184 states
that this statue by MscMonnies is to be erected here by the
Sons of the Rovolution.
MacMonnies exhibited this in the Paris Salon of 1891
and was awarded a second gold medal, this being the first time
an American sculptor had attained this honor.
Nnte the subway construction in the midground. Evidently
the City Hall station and loop of the I.R.T. is in progress.
1900-01
Gift of Urbrock Collection
MAY BE R9CPRODUCED

718951f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [City Hall.]
718951f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view northward from the easterly
side (Park Row at right) to show the distinctive Municipal
Building at Chambers Street. Outlined agwinst the lower portion of
same is the Brooklyn 8ridge extension and a Christmas tree. On the

718906f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - New York County Court House; Hall of Records.
718906f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A northeasterly view of the City Hall, showing
the westerly and southerly sides of same. To the right is the old
Brooklyn Bridge train shed over Park Row and to the left, the County
Court House. Note the absence of the Pulitzer Building at the right.
This was erected in 1889-90 on the site formerly occupied by
French's Hotel. A clearance there evidently dates this view.
About 1889
Gift of W. A. Lucas
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS
2) The Hall of REcords in City Hall Park.
Photo by J.J.Corell  About 1900
Fromm P.L.Sperr Collection

718902f.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Fountain - statue of "Civic Virtue"].
718902f.text:
City Hall Park as photographed northeastward from the
24th floor of the New York Telephone \&: Telegraph Bldg.
Shown is the newly added portion at the apex of this tri-
angular civic zone. This was until recently the site of
the old Post Office and Fedoral Bldg. The fountain-sta-
tue ''Civic Virtue'' by MacMonnies still stands in front of
the City Hall. This is to be removed to Queens and placed
near the new Borough Hall. Note the old ''Tweed'' County
Court House, the new Hall of Records, and the base of the
Municipal Bldg. in the background. Broadway is on the left
while on the right is Park Row.
NWEG ~ 320~2
3378
July 2, 1940
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31st St., N.Y.C.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE
718902f.folder: City Hall Park & [Fountain & statue of "Civic Virtue"]., Manhattan, NY

statue and No. 3, the trees between the City Hall (left) and the old

718901f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [View of upper downtown skyline.]
718901f-a.text:
New York City: A remarkable view of ugper downtown skyline from th
Northeast showing how completely the Woblworth Building, 60 stories,
792 feet high, dominates its surroundings. At the extreme left is
the tower of the Sing;er Building; alongside the Woolworth is the
far less attractive Transportation Huilding. Far to the right is the
New York Telephone Building. The old three cornered building is the
old main post office and Federal Building. and the building in the
foreground is the City Hall.
Sept. 1929  Ewing Galloway
718901f-a.folder: City Hall Park & [View of upper downtown skyline.], Manhattan, NY

718926f-a.title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.
718926f-a.text:
City Hall Park: A view of the New York City Hall, when the Tweed Ring
was building the County Court House. The wooden struoture shown atop the
latter was placed there, so that the public could not observe the slow
progress being made. It cost the City '8,O00,O00 more than it should
have; Tweed and his Ring taking the money.
About 18757
rown Bros.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
